introduction.p: This project can be used to motivate the concept of a group.

statement.p: Given any graph, G, it is trivial to see that G is isomorphic to itself. The identity function i: G\rightarrow G satisfies the conditions of an isomorphism. Such a function is called an automorphism of G. For some graphs, there are other functions that are also automorphisms. For example, any bijection on the vertices of a K_n is an automorphism of the K_n. This is an extreme case. A slightly more interesting example is that of path graph with three vertices.

statement.p:
The function, t, defined by t(1)=3, t(2)=2, \textrm{ and }t(3)=1 is an isomophism. We verify by noting that
\{1,2\} is an edge, and \{t(1),t(2)\}=\{3,2\} is an edge, and
\{2,3\} is an edge, and \{t(2),t(3)\}=\{2,1\} is an edge.
Thus, the this path graph has two automorphisms.
